main.java.GUINew

Class EnigmaSingleton

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.util.Observable
      • main.java.GUINew.EnigmaSingleton

  • public class EnigmaSingleton
extends java.util.Observable
    Uses the Singleton and Observer design patterns to enable data sharing across the various modular GUI pieces. Maintains state consistency for _the_ instance of EnigmaMachine and provides conveniency methods for manipulating it and performing encryption. Is thread safe. The rotor options are represented as an integer numbered 0-9. The rotors are mapped as follows: 0 - Rotor I; 1 - Rotor II; 2 - Rotor III; 3 - Rotor IV; 4 - Rotor V; 5 - Rotor VI; 6 - Rotor VII; 7 - Rotor VIII; 9 - Rotor Beta; 10 - Rotor Gamma Reflector options are also represented as an integer. The options are numbered 0-3, and are mapped as follows: 0 - Reflector B; 1 - Reflector C; 2 - Reflector B thin; 3 - Reflector C thin Ring and rotor settings are represented using characters. Plugboards are represented through a string that indicates their replacement mapping. Letters are swapped with their adjacent letters. For example, a string of "ABCD" swaps A's with B's (and vice-versa) and C's with D's. The updateType is an integer indicating what type of update or reset is to be performed. 0 means that only the rotor indicators are to be updated. The rotor positions change with every character encryption. 1 means that the GUI is to be fully reset to its default position. 2 means that only the text boxes are to be cleared. The spacesOption is an integer used to determine the spacing in the output. The default setting is no spaces, indicated by a 0. 1 indicates "words" of four letters, 2 indicates "words" of five letters, and 3 indicates that the original spacing should be maintained. This information is maintained here because the original spacing processing must be performed during the input processing. The machineTypes is an integer from 0 - 5 indicating the available machine type options. The machine type are mapped as follows 0 - No Restrictions, 1 - Enigma I; 2 - Enigma M3 Army; 3 - Enigma M4 Naval; 4 - Enigma M4 R1; 5 - Enigma M4 R2;
    Version:
    0.9 - 30 Nov 2013
    Author:
    Bryan Winstead, Team Enigma

    • Method Detail

      • setState

        public void setState(int[] rotorChoices,
            int reflectorChoice,
            char[] ringSettings,
            char[] initialPositions,
            java.lang.String plugboardMap)
        Sets the full state, including plugboardMap and initialPositions. Mostly used as an initial constructor for the EnigmaMachine. Also used for reset functionality.
        Parameters:
        rotorChoices - Array of 3-4 integers numbered 0-9 to determine which rotors to be included in the Enigma.
        reflectorChoice - An integer from 0-3 indicating which of the four available reflectors to include.
        ringSettings - An array of 3-4 characters indicating the rotors' ring settings.
        initialPositions - An array of 3-4 characters indicating the rotors' initial positions.
        plugboardMap - String indicating the plugboard replacement mapping. Letters are swapped with their adjacant letters. For example, a string of "ABCD" swaps A's with B's (and vice-versa) and C's with D's.

      • setState

        public void setState(int[] rotorChoices,
            int reflectorChoice,
            char[] ringSettings)
        Only sets the rotorChoices, reflectorChoice, and ringSettings.
        Parameters:
        rotorChoices - Array of 3-4 integers.
        reflectorChoice - Array of 3-4 letters.
        ringSettings - Array of 3-4 letters.

        public void setPositions(char[] rotorPositions)

        Parameters:
        rotorPositions - Array of 3-4 letters.

      • setInitPositions

        public void setInitPositions()
        Sets the machine's current rotor positions to its "initial" positions Useful for the Indicator Reset when encrypting/decrypting multiple messages of the same key and starting indicators.

        public void indicatorReset()

      • encryptChar

        public char encryptChar(char c)
        Performs encryption on a character at a time using the current machine state. Then calls notifyObservers() to pass the new machine state back to the GUI components, which then update.
        Parameters:
        c - the char to encrypt
        Returns:
        encryptedChar the encrypted char

      • encryptString

        public java.lang.String encryptString(java.lang.String s)
        Performs encryption on an entire string using the current machine state. Then calls notifyObserevrs() to pass the new machine state back to the GUI components, which then update.
        Parameters:
        s - String to be sent to the Enigma Machine for encryption.
        Returns:
        String that has been encrypted.
